positive.review: I watched Real Civil Engineer play this game and really enjoyed watching. Turns out I also really enjoy playing! By day, work a real job that pays money... by night, work a pretend job as a car dealer and get paid in enjoyment instead!

I think this game is designed wonderfully. The process of the upgrade of the property is a first time experience for me. It's really amazing how it converts as you level up. 

I've been playing this game for a little while now. Very addicting. (currently 72.7 hours). I've maxed out most things, but I'm still working on trophies. I only have 1. lol I've been working hard, bringing in new cars. 

When I search the cars available, I make sure to check some options, like *sort by price*, and I like to show only the cars that need work that I can give it. Early on, it can be a bit tough. I stayed up all night (in-game) working on cars when I first began. When dawn would hit, I would wait for a good time of day (sunlight affects pictures of vehicles), take pictures, post the ad, open business, and wait. 

They start coming in, and you can influence some with treats (cigarettes or gum), but only on the last round of bartering. It doesn't always work for me, but it's okay. I don't really need it now. But, it has helped me sell some cars for nifty prices. :D 

With the sale price, I change the price to something that is in the green, not blue. Blue is too easy to sell. You can sell the ones in green. Just may have to wait for the right buyer. :)

Jobs: Sell cars, wash cars (ultimate wash when upgraded), repair body, repair internal parts of car, repair parts, fueling of vehicles, purchasing things (There are hours of operation for these other businesses you can visit, and these places are typically closed on Sunday, unless they devs change it). So, check the time before you head out. They might be closed. You will have many roles at first. With a little time, you can hire help and create an assembly line, so-to-speak. Get a routine going. :D 

Ease of use is really good. I can perform actions really quickly on keyboard and mouse. I love that! Common keys. :D 

I don't recall starting settings, but I do not have any drama, just sales. :) I got a few loans to get started. Can get a loan on the spot. :D So, if you are out and about, and broke,  but want to buy a vehicle, open your tablet and apply. :D It's that easy. 

I love driving in here (and in most games). I use the brakes a lot for turns. The weight of the trailer can affect turns so practice a bit. 

The devs have been working hard on this game. Adjusting this, adjusting that. I am impressed! :) Go Garage Monkeys! Very nice job on this game! Very nice.

Thanks for reading. For more information, please read other reviews, and if you desire, check Community Hub/Discussions for more comments,  announcements and concerns.

Multiple Save Slots! ♥

Happy Gaming!

Edit: By the way, I think the bar is boring. IDK about others, but I don't really go there.

I didnt see any use for the underground car storage or even the additional tank for my onsite gas pump.  Leveling up to get more expensive cars, or the second part repair machine, didnt really interest me. At this point, Ill probably sit on the game for a few months to see if the updates stay consistent and the game grows. Car Dealer Simulator delivers! The game itself is straight forward what you would expect from a sim like this.
It has an ever expanding library of cars, a progression system that makes sense with some quality of life features that help you avoiding micromanagement of all aspects of the game.
Kudos to that: The NPC hired hands do a fabulous job, much better than in many other games. Updates are frequent and meaningful, far from abandonware.

Things I think need improvement:
- driving physics: Brakes don't really do anything - you hit them and the vehicles just keep going.
- impact of broken parts on driving behavior: You can have a suspension with 1% remaining and the car drives just the same as 100%. Same with engine, and the sound of a broken muffler is just the same as a new one.
- overhaul the assets of buildings, rubble, and other aspects of the map. The map itself is not that big, and for that, you should have a more polished look.
- the ability to change the game speed and/or ratio of the day/night cycle. Especially for streaming or YT videos, having at least less night or toggle daylight only would be helpful.

What I think would be a cool idea, but maybe not feasible to implement:
- a taxi service back to home.
- an apartment or house to live in and decorate. This could be combined with unique events driving engagement with the content, e.g. a New Year's 2026 Champagne bottle or such.

Now, overall, these are just minor things - don't get me wrong: The game is fun as it is - it just could be more fun ;-)

Im absolutely gutted to write a bad review for this game, because it has the world of potential under its feet. I thought it was an early access title, then realised it wasn't and I was playing a final product (Albeit with updates incoming but not the point).

First, why its SO GOOD:

- Addictive.
- Finding a bargain and making money gib dopamine
- Felt like genuine progression for the first few levels with huge progression on the horizon....

....But its at a few levels in you realise, that what you have been doing, is pretty much it for the entire game. Buy a car, do it up (Or have one of your mechanics do it), sell it for profit. Rinse, repeat. There isn't a game beyond a certain point.

Also - Fuel Station at home? a 100+ car park? Who the heck needed those? You sell cars the same day you put them on sale, and you are individually responsible for moving them around. Imagine if you had 100 cars to run around to each and every station!?

You can buy a Tow Truck and its upgrade for $60k which makes picking up cars only 10% easier as you can carry two, but you can't pickup two large ones, so negates the point completely. Furthermore, you can tow large vehicles with the base standard trailer hitch you get.

I found car sales pricing to be extremely patchy. I would buy one "Porsche" and make it perfect, sell for £60k, the next for £80k, even though the mileage and year were extremely similar. Sometimes I would get random beaters that fetched in immense cash, and others that weren't worth the hassle, but figuring it out was actually very difficult.

Automation would be nice here - Create a production line eventually where you can oversee it, what comes in (Quality vs Quantity), oversee pricing vs competition and the market, etc.

I really wish the devs the best because this is a cracking effort, but getting to this point in just a short few days has left me gutted.

Im absolutely gutted to write a bad review for this game, because it has the world of potential under its feet. I thought it was an early access title, then realised it wasn't and I was playing a final product (Albeit with updates incoming but not the point).

First, why its SO GOOD:

- Addictive.
- Finding a bargain and making money gib dopamine
- Felt like genuine progression for the first few levels with huge progression on the horizon....

....But its at a few levels in you realise, that what you have been doing, is pretty much it for the entire game. Buy a car, do it up (Or have one of your mechanics do it), sell it for profit. Rinse, repeat. There isn't a game beyond a certain point.

Also - Fuel Station at home? a 100+ car park? Who the heck needed those? You sell cars the same day you put them on sale, and you are individually responsible for moving them around. Imagine if you had 100 cars to run around to each and every station!?

You can buy a Tow Truck and its upgrade for $60k which makes picking up cars only 10% easier as you can carry two, but you can't pickup two large ones, so negates the point completely. Furthermore, you can tow large vehicles with the base standard trailer hitch you get.

I found car sales pricing to be extremely patchy. I would buy one "Porsche" and make it perfect, sell for £60k, the next for £80k, even though the mileage and year were extremely similar. Sometimes I would get random beaters that fetched in immense cash, and others that weren't worth the hassle, but figuring it out was actually very difficult.

Automation would be nice here - Create a production line eventually where you can oversee it, what comes in (Quality vs Quantity), oversee pricing vs competition and the market, etc.

I really wish the devs the best because this is a cracking effort, but getting to this point in just a short few days has left me gutted.
Spawn in trapped under the tow truck and my player is stuck in the ground. No button to get player unstuck or a reset.

The game is completely unplayable, full of bugs, the more stuff and cars you have, the more and more bugs are appearing, every auto-save the game freezes, it even started to freeze without auto-save, good idea for a game but very bad execution, plus it becomes repetitive and boring

The content of the game is way too low it needs more things to do. It’s fun for about 2–3 hours and keeps you hooked with the shop upgrades, but it still needs more. Hopefully, we’ll get new content soon, along with some UI improvements and performance tweaks.

This game is mostly fun. But it feels like it's crafted to be an idle game but with none of the features of an idle game. The progress is really slow with more than a few noob traps (don't buy the gas hub or the fuel tank it's not a gas station like I thought) and you don't really have the chance to walk away and let your car dealership run while your employees do it because most employees can't be hired until the 3rd upgrades. Most of the story pauses for a really long time. A quest said advance to Reputation level 3 and I completed that within the first 2-3 hours of the game. The next quest was advance to Reputation level 7. I thought oh maybe I'll hit it in another 3 hours. Almost 9 hours later I'm still not there. I get that it's an early access simulator game so they're all supposed to be really low quality (that's part of the charm) but this one feels like it's trying to be an idle game instead but starting you off in a very tedious version of a simulator game. I'd recommend lowering some of the values to speed up progress no matter which way you decide to take the game.

I found car sales pricing to be extremely patchy. I would buy one "Porsche" and make it perfect, sell for £60k, the next for £80k, even though the mileage and year were extremely similar. Sometimes I would get random beaters that fetched in immense cash, and others that weren't worth the hassle, but figuring it out was actually very difficult.

Automation would be nice here - Create a production line eventually where you can oversee it, what comes in (Quality vs Quantity), oversee pricing vs competition and the market, etc.

I really wish the devs the best because this is a cracking effort, but getting to this point in just a short few days has left me gutted.
